title.narrative: Comprehensive Approach to Health System Strengthening

description.narrative: The development objectives of Comprehensive Approach to Health System Strengthening Project for Comoros are: (i) To improve utilization of quality PHC; and (ii) strengthen capacity of institutions which are critical to quality PHC. This project has four components.1) The first component, Improving PHC infrastructure, workforce, and service delivery platforms, has the following subcomponents: (i) Supporting the rehabilitation of PHC facilities (district health centers and health posts) and the provision of PHC equipment and vehicles; (ii) Improving PHC workforce; (iii) Supporting the PBF scheme in PHC; and (iv) Scaling up the community health platform. 2) The second component, Strengthening institutions and governance, aims to support the strengthening and operationalization of selected institutions and governance structures which are critical to (i) quality PHC and (ii) disease outbreak response. 3) The third component, Citizen engagement and empowerment, project management, monitoring and evaluation, aims to finance the following subcomponents: (i) Citizen engagement, patient empowerment and other patient support; and (ii) Project management and project monitoring and evaluation. 4) The fourth component, Contingent Emergency Response Component (CERC), aims to support for urgent need of assistance or capacity constraints of the World Bank Policy for investment project financing (IPF) .

condition.narrative: Schedule 2- Section II. C The Recipient shall take all action required on its behalf to establish, not later than six (6) monthsafter the Effective Date, and thereafter maintain and operate, a functional grievance handling mechanism for the Project, withadequate staffing and processes for registering grievances and acceptable to the Association, thereby ensuring the ongoingimprovement on service delivery under the Project.

Schedule 2-Section I.A.2. the Recipient shall strengthen the PIU, with the recruitment, not later than three months after theEffective Date, an internal auditor, a financial officer, a chief accountant and an accountant, all under terms of reference andwith qualifications and experience satisfactory to the Association

title.narrative: PHC facilities with accreditation level 2 above as per the facility accreditation program
PHC facilities participating in the PBF scheme supported by the project which reimburses for both quantity and quality of service
People who have received essential health, nutrition, and population (HNP) services
Number of women and children who have received basic nutrition services
Number of deliveries attended by skilled health personnel
Annual District and National Health Assemblies
PHC facilities renovated (minor renovations) and/or equipped among the PHC structures in need of these renovations and/or equipment (percentage)
National Health Strategies and Plans adopted (Quality of Care, NCDs, Human Resources for Health) (number)
Operational hotline for patient complaints and feedbacks

target.value: Emergency Action Plan officially validated before CERC activation

title.narrative: PHC health workers receiving annual CME
PHC health workers benefiting from annual clinical mentorship and/or coaching
Patient associations/support groups established (diabetes, hypertension, chronic lung diseases, cancer)
Revision of the pre-service nurse training curriculum to make it competency-based
PHC facilities self-monitoring a set of quality of care indicator quarterly for quality improvement
Primary health care facilities submitting monthly report according to national guidelines
Recipients of scholarships for pre-service training in selected clinical disciplines, public health and health management
Nationally representative patient experience surveys conducted
Community health workers trained to provide health and nutrition services
PHC facilities with at least one quality improvement initiative with the team based problem solving approach
Functional Emergency Medical Transportation with a dedicated hotline on each island
Community health workers trained to provide health and nutrition services
